header_summary:
The recent discussions within the Bitcoin community have illuminated several key areas of innovation and debate, notably around label scanning efficiency, economic policy adjustments, and protocol activation strategies. The revision of common beliefs about label scanning scalability within SP wallets, as highlighted in discussions around BIP-352, suggests that efficiency can be significantly improved by adopting a reverse lookup method, challenging the traditional view that label scanning faces inherent scalability issues. This method, supported by module PR 1765, demonstrates that scanning costs do not necessarily increase with the number of labels, potentially enabling full-node wallets to manage large quantities of labels without performance degradation ([source](https://gnusha.org/pi/bitcoindev/59b1879d-b43d-41ac-9b3e-3e65cf31d4e5n@googlegroups.com/T/#ma25b2a2b7c0342efe823ca51e5aa0f95e673e013)).

In the economic domain, the Bitcoin community has reacted to the lowered default minimum relay feerate to 0.1 sat/vB, indicating a shift towards enhancing transaction consolidation at the wallet or user experience level rather than through protocol or policy changes. This adjustment reflects a broader understanding that Bitcoin's economic strategies must remain adaptable and mindful of the marketplace's realities, emphasizing the value of feedback and open discourse in shaping effective cryptocurrency policies ([source](https://gnusha.org/pi/bitcoindev/CAOj3_X8cJLJChvv3-QSGA8j5MVwgYxn1BAUeugTTgiqUWzEK_Q@mail.gmail.com/T/#mb5720bad34ecc7ff3224b89c783a7d2e9cf96635)).

Regarding protocol advancements, the community's consensus on using BIP 9 for the cautious activation of BIP 119 during a recent IRC meeting illustrates a collaborative and feedback-oriented approach to implementing significant changes within the Bitcoin network. This decision-making process highlights the community's preference for conservative and consensus-driven development strategies to ensure network improvements are both thoughtful and inclusive ([source](https://gnusha.org/pi/bitcoindev/CALiT-Zr9JnLcohdUQRufM42OwROcOh76fA1xjtqUkY5=otqfwg@mail.gmail.com/T/#u#m66f16e256d87d4407d7b1b2cb2ea528aa9b8348d)).

Lastly, discussions around terminology and innovative protocols, such as a Layer 3 solution for trustless custody, underscore the ongoing efforts to refine Bitcoin's functionality and user experience. The proposal for a Layer 3 protocol addresses crucial challenges like transaction speed, high fees, and the reliance on trust, proposing a system of auditable cryptographic ledgers and a network of bonded custodians to enhance scalability and usability without compromising decentralization. This and other dialogues reflect a vibrant community committed to exploring and debating ideas that could shape the future of Bitcoin ([source](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/a-proposal-for-trustless-custody/2173)).

recent_posts.title: Major BIP 360 Update
recent_posts.summary:
- The term initially thought to describe a `scriptPubKey` is misleading.
- It represents a Merkle root, not merely a tapscript hash.
- "Pay to script tree merkle root" is suggested for clarity and accuracy.
